Question

A chess tournament has KKK levels and N=2KN = 2^KN=2K players with skills P1>P2>...>PNP_1 > P_2 > ... >P_{N}P1​>P2​>...>PN​. At each level, random pairs are formed and one person from each pair proceeds to the next level. When two opponents play, the one with the better skills always wins. What is the probability that players P1P_1P1​ and P2P_2P2​ will meet in the final level?

Hint

if two players meet before the final, they don't meet at the final.

Answer

N2(N−1)\dfrac{N}{2(N-1)}2(N−1)N​

Solution

Consider K=1,N=2K=1, N=2K=1,N=2, the probability is 1.

Consider K=2,N=4K=2, N=4K=2,N=4; the first round can be in the following ways:

  1. (P1×P2)×(P3×P4)(P_1 \times P_2 ) \times ( P_3 \times P_4 )(P1​×P2​)×(P3​×P4​)
  2. (P1×P3)×(P2×P4)(P_1 \times P_3 ) \times ( P_2 \times P_4 )(P1​×P3​)×(P2​×P4​)
  3. (P1×P4)×(P2×P3)(P_1 \times P_4 ) \times ( P_2 \times P_3 )(P1​×P4​)×(P2​×P3​)

They don't meet in finals in the first case (out of a total of three). Thus, for K=2,N=4K=2, N=4K=2,N=4, the probability that they meet is 2/32/32/3.

Assume that instead of forming random pairs at each level, we have already constructed a "tournament tree", which is a binary tree. At the bottom of this structure, we have the initial NNN players. Each node represents the match between the two children (players), and the value of each node is the player who won that match. The value of the top-level root node is the overall winner of the tournament.

With this image, we can see the whole tournament is deterministic and only depends on the initial arrangement of players (at the bottom level). We also notice that the two players who reach the final level are the best players of the left half of the tree and the right of the tree (respectively).

Imagine NNN players getting partitioned into two groups of N/2N/2N/2 players each, with player P1P_1P1​ topping in the first group and player P2P_2P2​ in the second. The best player of each partition reaches the final. The probability that a random partition separates player P1P_1P1​ from P2P_2P2​ is (N/2)(N−1)\dfrac{(N/2)}{(N-1)}(N−1)(N/2)​

Here's how: There are NNN empty slots in a sequence at the bottom layer of the tournament tree. We can start assigning players from P1P_1P1​. Suppose P1P_1P1​ is assigned to a slot in the first half. For P2P_2P2​, there are total N−1N-1N−1 slots remaining, and N/2N/2N/2 are in a new group (that does not contain P1P_1P1​). Hence, there are (N/2)(N/2)(N/2) favorable choices and N−1N-1N−1 total choices.

Hence the probability is N2(N−1)\dfrac{N}{2(N-1)}2(N−1)N​

Note: The question says that we are forming random pairs at each level. But that is equivalent to retroactively constructing the bottom-layer of the tournament tree, in any desirable fashion.

For example, consider at the iiith level, we randomly decide to match PjP_jPj​ with PkP_kPk​, even though they were not siblings in the tree at that level. That's fine, we can modify the tree such that now PjP_jPj​ and PkP_kPk​ are siblings, while keeping the entire branch below each of those nodes intact.
